INTRACAPSULAR FEMORAL NECK FRACTURE

 

  • Intracapsular femoral neck fractures (FNFs) account for approximately 50% of all hip fractures.
  • Intracapsular fractures demonstrate limited healing potential due to the absence of the periosteal layer, so the fracture is only immersed in the surrounding synovial fluid. 
  • These injuries occur secondary to low-energy falls in older individuals and higher-energy traumatic mechanisms in younger patients. 
  • However, most of these fractures occur in older people with underlying osteoporosis.
  • Displaced intracapsular femoral neck fractures in older people are typically managed with hip reconstruction procedures – the femoral head and neck are replaced with a reconstruction prosthesis.
  • These procedures include hip hemiarthroplasty or total hip arthroplasty (THA).
  • Non-displaced fractures may be managed with fixation using cannulated screw fixation.
  • Hemiarthroplasty, or femoral head replacement, is recommended for displaced intracapsular FNFs, especially in older patients with low activity levels.
  • THA is preferred for patients with intact ambulatory function or evidence of hip pain and degenerative arthritis.
  • Girdlestone resection arthroplasty (GRA) may be an option for patients who are unsuitable for hemiarthroplasty due to conditions like systemic infections or severe neurological impairment.
  • Hemiarthroplasty and THA are contraindicated in patients with an active hip infection.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Russell’s traction: This is a non-surgical method used for younger patients with femoral neck fracture with good bone quality. It might not be ideal for an 80-year-old due to potential complications from prolonged immobilization.

 

Option B. Bar and boot plaster: This non-surgical method also has limitations for elderly patients due to healing complications.

 

Option C. Intramedullary nailing: This surgical procedure uses nails to fix the fracture. While it can be an option, it might be risky for an 80-year-old's bone quality.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hemiarthroplasty is a surgical procedure where the damaged femoral head is replaced with an artificial joint, preserving the patient's own socket.
  • This offers a good balance between pain relief, mobility, and surgical complexity for elderly patients with this type of fracture.
  • The most appropriate management option for an 80-year-old patient with an intracapsular femoral neck fracture is Hemiarthroplasty.

questions.text: Identify the classification used and grade of the shown injury in a child. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gartland’s classification Type III

 

The X-ray provided shows a Supracondylar fracture of the humerus, which is classified using the Gartland classification system. The Gartland classification is specifically for supracondylar fractures, particularly in children.

 

  • Gartland Type III refers to a completely displaced fracture, with no cortical contact between the fragments. There may be either medial or lateral displacement, as seen in this case.
  • The Salter-Harris classification is used for epiphyseal plate injuries, not for supracondylar fractures. Therefore, it is not applicable in this scenario.

 

To summarize:

 

  • Gartland Type I: Undisplaced fracture.
  • Gartland Type II: Displaced fracture with the posterior cortex intact.
  • Gartland Type III: Displaced fracture with no cortical contact (either medial or lateral displacement).
  • Gartland Type IV: An intraoperative diagnosis where the periosteum is damaged both anteriorly and posteriorly, requiring more complex reduction techniques.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salter-Harris classification Type III: Incorrect because the injury in question is not an epiphyseal fracture. Salter-Harris classification is used for growth plate fractures, not supracondylar fractures.

 

Option C. Gartland’s classification Type IV: Incorrect because Gartland Type IV is an intraoperative diagnosis, which is not apparent in the provided X-ray.

 

Option D. Salter-Harris classification Type IV: Again, incorrect because this classification system pertains to epiphyseal injuries, and the X-ray shows a supracondylar fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gartland classification is specifically used for supracondylar humerus fractures in children, while the Salter-Harris classification is used for growth plate (epiphyseal) fractures.

 

Gartland classification Supracondylar humerus

 

  • Type 1: Undisplaced
  • Type 2: Displaced with posterior hinge intact
  • Type 3a: Displaced fracture with lateral hinge broken (PM)
  • Type 3b: Displaced fracture with medial hinge broken (PL)
  • Type 4: Completely displaced with both anterior and posterior periosteum avulsed (Intra-operative finding)

 

 

Salter-Harris classification of epiphyseal injuries

 

  • Type I: Fracture line is entirely with in Physis causing epiphyseal slip
  • Type II: Fracture line extends from physis into the Metaphysis (Thurston-Holland’s fragment sign)
  • Type III: Fracture line extends from physis into the Epiphysis causing epiphyseal split
  • Type IV: Fracture line extends across the Epiphysis,  (articular surface), Physis, and metaphysis
  • Type V: Crush injury of physis with initially normal X-rays

questions.text: A 26-year-old female suffers a proximal 1/3rd Femoral shaft fracture. What would be the ideal treatment option?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intramedullary nailing

 

FEMORAL SHAFT FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • Treatment of femoral shaft fractures can be operative or non-operative.
  • Operative fixation with intramedullary nailing is the gold standard treatment.
  • Other operative techniques include plate osteosynthesis and external fixation.
  • Closed treatment with traction, splinting, and casting may be temporary treatment.

 

Intramedullary Nailing

 

  • Intramedullary nailing (IMN) is the gold standard of treatment for femoral shaft fractures.
  • Early treatment in a stable patient within 24-48 hours reduces the incidence of pulmonary complications, infection, and mortality.
  • Delayed treatment increases pulmonary complications in up to 56% of patients compared to only 16% of patients treated early.
  • The insertion site of an IMN is outside the zone of injury, preserving the surrounding blood flow and retain the hematoma that contains beneficial bone growth factors.
  • It provides a strong and stable internal fixation that allows for early mobilization and weight-bearing, which is crucial for promoting healing and preventing complications.
  • It is a minimally invasive surgical procedure compared to other options like plate fixation, resulting in less tissue disruption and blood loss.
  • It helps in a faster recovery time and a quicker return to daily activities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hip Spica: This is a cast that extends from the waist to the toes and is not typically used for femoral shaft fractures due to the limited mobility it allows.

 

Option B. Above Knee Slab: An above-knee slab is a temporary cast that can be used for pain management and swelling reduction but doesn't provide enough stability for healing a fractured femoral shaft.

 

Option C. Above Knee Cast: Similar to an above-knee slab, a cast offers limited stability and wouldn't be suitable for the long-term treatment of this fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intramedullary nailing is the treatment option of choice in proximal femoral shaft fractures as it is minimally invasive and provides faster recovery.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with growth on talus as seen on foot x-ray. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteochondroma

 

  • Osteochondroma is a common benign bone tumor that typically presents as a growth on the bone with a cartilage cap. 
  • In this case, the boy has a growth on the talus, which is characteristic of osteochondroma.
  • X-ray Findings: On x-ray, osteochondroma appears as a bone growth projecting from the surface, often with a cartilaginous cap that is not visible on the x-ray itself since cartilage is radiolucent.
  • Presentation: Patients often notice a palpable mass, which feels larger than what is seen on the x-ray due to the cartilage component (as radiolucent).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enchondroma: This is a benign cartilaginous tumor that occurs inside the bone (endosteal). It is more common in small bones of the hands and feet and does not present as an external growth.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma: This is a malignant bone tumor typically found in the metaphyses of long bones, such as around the knee. It presents as a destructive bone lesion with a periosteal reaction, often not seen in the talus.

 

 

Option C. Osteomyelitis: This is an infection of the bone that leads to inflammation. It usually shows a solid periosteal reaction or lytic cavities on x-ray and does not present as a growth. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image shows growth in the talus which is characteristic of osteochondroma of the talus bone. 
  • Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor presenting as a palpable growth with a cartilaginous cap, most often found in young adults, and visible on x-ray as a bony projection.

questions.text: Which muscle is inserted on the lesser trochanter of the femur? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Psoas major

 

  • Psoas major muscle is a paraspinal muscle located deep in the body.
  • It lays close to the spine on either side and extends distally to the brim of the lesser pelvis.
  • It acts to laterally flex the lumbar spine and assists with flexion and external rotation of the hip.
  • It is essential for correct standing or sitting lumbar posture, stability of the hip joint, and during walking and running.
  • The psoas muscle is one of the core muscles.
  • The psoas muscle contains superficial and deep parts.
  • Superficially, it originates along the lateral surface of the distal thoracic vertebrae and adjacent intervertebral discs.
  • The deeper portion originates at the first 4 lumbar vertebrae.
  • The fibres of the muscle converge from its wide origin as they descend on the posterior abdominal wall.
  • They cross the pelvic inlet to form a long tendon, which is joined within the pelvic region by fibres from the iliacus muscle, finally inserting into the lesser trochanter of the femur. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Psoas minor: The psoas minor muscle originates along the lateral aspect of the vertebral body of the 12th thoracic vertebrae and the 1st lumbar vertebrae, and the intervertebral disc between those two vertebrae. There are two psoas minors, one on each side of the spine. Distally, it blends with the iliopsoas fascia. It inserts into the pectineal line of the pubis (not always present).

 

 

Option C. Obturator internus: The obturator internus muscle originates from the inferior margin of the superior pubic ramus and from the pelvic surface of the obturator membrane. Its tendon exits the pelvis through the lesser sciatic foramen to insert onto the greater trochanter of the femur.

 

 

Option D. Piriformis: It originates from the anterior aspect of the sacrum at the level of S2-S4, sacrotuberous ligament, and periphery of the greater sciatic notch. It inserts on the superior and medial aspects of the greater trochanter.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Psoas Major muscle inserts at the lesser trochanter of the femur and is involved in flexing the hip joint.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe back ache and the following x-ray after an RTA. Diagnose the fracture present. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Chance fracture

 

The image presented shows a spine injury, and based on the clinical scenario (a patient presenting after an RTA or road traffic accident), the fracture pattern described fits that of a Chance fracture. A Chance fracture, also known as a flexion-distraction injury or seatbelt fracture, typically occurs due to high-force flexion injuries, such as in a car accident where a seatbelt restrains the lower body while the upper body moves forward. This type of fracture involves a horizontal break extending through all three spinal columns (anterior, middle, and posterior)

 

The Chance fracture goes from anterior to posterior, involving all three columns, which is a hallmark feature of this injury. The description matches the flexion-distraction mechanism associated with this fracture.

 

Additional Information

 

Common spine fractures:

 

  1. Jefferson fracture:
    • Also called a ring fracture of the atlas (C1 vertebra).
    • Mnemonic: JAT.
  2. Hangman's fracture:
    • Fracture through the interarticularis of the C2 vertebra, causing a slip of C2 over C3 (spondylolisthesis).
    • Mnemonic: H2 (Hangman’s fracture, C2 vertebra).
  3. Whiplash injury:
    • Occurs due to hyperextension followed by flexion (e.g., in a high-speed vehicle accident where the vehicle suddenly stops).
    • Resembles the motion of a whiplash.
  4. Wedge fracture:
    • The anterior height of the vertebral body is lowered while the posterior height remains normal.
  5. Burst fracture:
    • Involves damage to the anterior, middle, and posterior columns of the vertebra.
    • The vertebral body is damaged, involving both the anterior and middle columns.
    • Atlas (Jefferson) fracture is also considered a burst fracture.
  6. Chance Fracture:
    • The force moves from anterior to posterior, going all the way to the spinous process.
    • Involves flexion of the body with a distraction force.
    • Also known as jackknife or seatbelt fracture.
  7. Hinge fracture: A fracture where the skull base is divided into two halves: anterior and posterior.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burst fracture: A burst fracture involves damage to the anterior and middle columns of the vertebra, with fragments spreading outwards. While a burst fracture may result from high-energy trauma, the image and clinical description provided in this question are more characteristic of a Chance fracture. The distribution of injury in a burst fracture does not typically extend through all three columns.

 

Option C. Compression fracture: Compression fractures generally affect the anterior part of the vertebra, causing a wedge-shaped deformity, but they do not involve the middle and posterior columns like the Chance fracture. These fractures are often seen in patients with osteoporosis rather than as a result of high-energy trauma.

 

Option D. Fracture of spinous process: A fracture of the spinous process (such as a Clay-shoveler's fracture) usually involves a break in the posterior part of the vertebra only and does not involve the anterior or middle columns. This type of fracture typically occurs from direct trauma or forceful flexion but doesn't match the findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Chance fracture is a flexion-distraction injury that extends through all three columns of the spine and is commonly seen in patients who experience a sudden forward motion, such as in a seatbelt-related injury during a car accident.
